content: Initial assessment of patient with excessive hair growth in a male pattern

children.content: Perform a history and physical examination to assess the severity of hirsutism
Treat with cosmetic approaches like bleaching, shaving, waxing, electrolysis, laser treatment, and the use of depilatory agents.
Measure plasma testosterone and free testosterone in the early morning
Testosterone level is normal or low
Polycystic ovary syndrome: diagnosed when the patient has at least two symptoms of chronic hyperandrogenism, oligo-ovulation or anovulation, and polycystic ovaries.
Metformin, Thiazolidinedione, Oral contraceptive pill, Spironolactone
Virilizing congenital adrenal hyperplasia: suggested by the premature growth of pubic hair and clitoromegaly.
Can be excluded by measuring the morning 17-alpha-hydroxyprogesterone level.

Acromegaly: suggested by the coarsening of facial features or by hand enlargement. Prolactinoma: suggested by the presence of galactorrhea and an elevated prolactin level. Cushing's syndrome: suggested by the development of truncal obesity, moon face, buffalo hump, purple striae, or proximal muscle weakness.
Refer to relevant chapters for further information
Androgen-secreting tumors are rare but should be considered among women with an acute presentation or those who have very high levels of testosterone (>200 ng/dl).
Evaluate with a level of dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS) and an abdominal and pelvic ultrasound.
Idiopathic hirsutism: the most common diagnosis after other disorders are excluded by clinical or laboratory features.
